nodes.description: Former President of France
French politician and statesman, identified as François Mitterrand in the provided text.
Served under President François Hollande
Founded a centrist and pro-European political movement
Elected President of France, defeating Marine Le Pen
Oversaw reforms to labour laws, taxation, and pensions during his presidency
Increasing protests against his reforms
Elected to a second term, again defeating Marine Le Pen
Government passed legislation raising the retirement age from 62 to 64, leading to public sector strikes and protests
Novel, an early work of the Naturalism movement exploring passion and crime.
Novel, a major work in the Rougon-Macquart series, depicting the social ills of alcoholism and poverty in working-class Paris.
Novel, part of the Rougon-Macquart series, portraying a courtesan in Second Empire France.
Novel, a seminal work of the Naturalist movement depicting a coal miners' strike and the struggles of the working class.
Novel, part of the Rougon-Macquart series, exploring themes of heredity, environment, and violence within human nature.
Renowned open letter published in L'Aurore, accusing the French government of antisemitism and obstruction of justice in the Dreyfus Affair.
Major political scandal and miscarriage of justice in France, in which Zola played a pivotal role as a public figure and journalist in the exoneration of Alfred Dreyfus.
Collection of short stories by Émile Zola
First novel in the Rougon-Macquart series by Émile Zola
Novel by Émile Zola, part of the Rougon-Macquart cycle
Novel by Émile Zola, part of the Rougon-Macquart cycle, focusing on a department store
Novel by Émile Zola, part of the Rougon-Macquart cycle, exploring the art world
Novel by Émile Zola, part of the Rougon-Macquart cycle, depicting the Franco-Prussian War
First novel in 'Les Trois Villes' series by Émile Zola
First novel in 'Les Quatre Évangiles' series by Émile Zola
French novelist, journalist, and playwright, known for naturalism and his role in the political liberalization of France.
An influential French film director, he directed the acclaimed 1938 film adaptation of La Bête Humaine.
A prominent French actor, he starred as Jacques Lantier in Jean Renoir's 1938 film adaptation of La Bête Humaine.
A French actress, she played Séverine Roubaud in the 1938 film adaptation of La Bête Humaine.
A Belgian-born French actor, he portrayed Roubaud in Jean Renoir's 1938 film La Bête Humaine.
A French army officer of Jewish descent, he was falsely accused of treason, becoming the central figure of the Dreyfus Affair that 'J'Accuse...!' protested.
A French statesman who served as Prime Minister, he was the editor of the newspaper 'L'Aurore' which published Émile Zola's 'J'Accuse...!'.
A French army officer and head of military intelligence, he uncovered evidence proving Alfred Dreyfus's innocence, at great personal cost.
A French army major, he was the real perpetrator of the treason for which Alfred Dreyfus was falsely convicted, as revealed during the Dreyfus Affair.
The elder brother of Alfred Dreyfus, he tirelessly campaigned for his brother's exoneration and played a crucial role in bringing the truth to light.
A French army officer who uncovered evidence that exonerated Dreyfus and implicated Major Esterházy.
A French army officer who was the true author of the 'bordereau' that led to Dreyfus's false conviction.
French peasant girl who reported seeing apparitions of the Virgin Mary, leading to the establishment of the Sanctuary of Lourdes.
Parish priest of Lourdes who initially challenged Bernadette's claims but later became a staunch supporter of the apparitions.
A quarryman who experienced the first officially recognized miraculous healing at Lourdes, recovering from blindness.
Local physician who observed and documented the events at Lourdes, providing early medical reports on the miraculous cures.
Pope during the time of the apparitions who officially approved the veneration of Our Lady of Lourdes in 1862.
Served as President of France from 2012 to 2017, during which Emmanuel Macron was appointed Minister of Economics and Finance.
Served as Prime Minister of France, leading the second Valls government in which Emmanuel Macron was appointed Economics Minister.
French politician who was defeated by Emmanuel Macron in the second round of the 2017 French Presidential Election.
French politician whose affair partly contributed to Emmanuel Macron's victory in the 2017 French Presidential Election.
As Minister of Labour, she was the key architect and implementer of Emmanuel Macron's 2017 labor law reforms.
As Prime Minister, he oversaw the government's legislative agenda, including the significant labor law reforms under President Macron.
As the head of France's largest trade union (CFDT), he played a central role in negotiations and reactions to Macron's labor reforms.
As the leader of the CGT, he was a prominent figure in opposing and organizing protests against Macron's labor law reforms.
As Prime Minister, she oversaw the government's efforts to pass the pension reforms.
He was the minister directly responsible for drafting and defending the 2023 pension reform bill.
She led the main left-wing opposition party's parliamentary efforts against the pension reform.
Served as the First Secretary of the French Socialist Party
Served as Mayor of the city of Tulle
Won the French Presidential Election, becoming President of France
Launched military intervention in Mali during his presidency
President during the November 2015 terrorist attacks in Paris
Signed international agreement on climate change
Authored a memoir reflecting on his presidency
Mitterrand led the Socialist Party before winning the presidency.

links.id: François Hollande-First Secretary of Socialist Party

links.label: Mitterrand led the party from 1971 to 1981 and ran as its candidate.
Hollande was First Secretary of the party (1997–2008).
Macron served under President Hollande as Deputy Secretary-General and Economy Minister.
